document.docAuthor: Viraktamath, C. A. & Yeshwanth, H. M.
document.masterDocTitle: Three new leafhopper species of Macropsis Lewis (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae Eurymelinae: Macropsini) with a key to species from the Indian subcontinent

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Three new leafhopper species of Macropsis Lewis (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae Eurymelinae: Macropsini) with a key to species from the Indian subcontinent

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Department of Entomology, University of Agricultural Sciences, GKVK, Bengaluru 560065, India.
Department of Entomology, University of Agricultural Sciences, GKVK, Bengaluru 560065, India. & hmyeshwanth @ gmail. com; https: // orcid. org / 0000 - 0002 - 5104 - 3401

paragraph.keyLead:
1. Head and thorax uniformly dark brown to black, forewing shining black except for a few hyaline cells ( Figs 2 A–B)............................................................................................
M. krishna
sp. nov .

- Head and thorax pale brown, brown speckled, green or green with tinge of yellow, grey speckled with brown; forewings grey or green with or without brown speckles ( Figs 1A , O–P, 3C–D)................................................. 2

2. Frontoclypeus with inverted V-shaped subocellar suture across bases of antennae ( Fig. 4B ); aedeagus strongly dorsally curved almost at right angle at midlength ( Fig. 10S )..........................................
M. karnatakana Viraktamath

3. Crown raised above level of pronotum ( Figs1 I–J)........................................
M. hamiltoni Viraktamath
- Crown not raised above level of pronotum ( Fig. 1 A–B, K–L).................................................. 4

5. Pro and mesothoracic femora piceous.................................................
M. shrideviae Viraktamath

- Pro and mesothoracic femora not piceous..............................................
M. campbelli Viraktamath
- Clypellus with lateral margins not depressed ( Fig. 3 L–P)...................................................... 8

7. Green species, forewings speckled with dark brown to black ( Figs 2 C–D); breed on species of
Acacia
...................................................................................
M. kundui Kameswara Rao & Ramakrishnan

- Pale brown species, forewing without dark brown to black speckles ( Figs 3 I–J); breed on species of
Ziziphus
...............................................................................................
M. ziziphi Viraktamath

8. Aedeagal shaft narrowest at midlength, apex rounded in lateral view ( Fig 10I ).................
M. ceylonica Viraktamath

9. Sternite VIII with lateral tuft of setae on either side ( Fig. 9J ); dorsal connective V or Y-shaped ( Fig. 10J ); breed on species of
Quercus
............................................................................................ 10

- Sternite VIII without such setae; dorsal connective either H-shaped or U-shaped ( Figs 5D , 6C , 8C ); breed on either
Acacia
or plants other than
Quercus
.............................................................................. 13

10. Pygofer ventral process with triangular lobe-like expansion at midlength ( Fig. 9H )................
M. smitae Viraktamath

11. Pygofer ventral process expanded subapically then tapered to apex ( Fig. 9I )..................
M. sympatrica Viraktamath
- Pygofer ventral process not so expanded subapically, more or less gradually narrowed towards apex ( Figs 9E , F–G)...... 12

12. Pygofer ventral process serrated at midlength ( Fig. 9E ); aedeagus with shaft slightly curved dorsally at midlength ( Fig. 10F )...................................................................................
M. irenae Viraktamath

- Pygofer ventral process not serrated at midlength ( Figs 9 F–G); aedeagus with shaft strongly curved dorsally at distal 1/3 ( Fig. 10G )............................................................................
M. nepalica Viraktamath

13. Relatively small species 2.4 to 3.1 mm long, with well-defined black spots on face, pronotum and mesonotum ( Figs 3 C–D, 4N)..............................................................................
M. sundara Viraktamath

- Relatively larger species more than 3.2 mm long (except
M. kolarensis
measuring 2.7 to 3.2 mm ) without black spots on head, pronotum and mesonotum............................................................................. 14
14. Pygofer ventral process short, not reaching dorsal margin ( Figs 6A , 8A,–B , 9 C–D)................................ 15
- Pygofer ventral process long either almost attaining dorsal margin or exceeding it ( Figs 5A , 9 A–B)................... 19
15. Pygofer ventral process short, confined to about basal half of posterior margin ( Figs 8 A–B, 9D)...................... 16

16. Aedeagal shaft short and stout in lateral view, about 3x as long as wide near base ( Fig. 8G )........
M. puttarudriahi
sp. nov .

17. Tergal apodemes wide apart ( Fig. 7J ).................................
M. delhiensis Kameswara Rao & Ramakrishnan

- Tergal apodemes either in contact medially or overlapping ( Fig. 7K ).......................
M. nigrolineata Viraktamath

18. Pro and meso tibiae with basal and apical 1/3 dark brown; aedeagus in lateral view dorsally curved before midlength and without dorsal keel ( Fig. 10R )...........................................................
M. vagdeviae Viraktamath

- Pro and meso tibiae without black markings; aedeagus in lateral view dorsally curved beyond midlength and with dorsal keel ( Fig. 10N )....................................................................
M. leucasasperae Viraktamath
- Proepimeron either uniformly brown or without black or dark brown spot ( Figs 3L, N , 4C, G )....................... 21

20. Meta tibia with basal black spot; aedeagus with shaft curved dorsally before midlength ( Fig. 10O ).....
M. sohii Viraktamath

- Meta tibia without basal black spot; aedeagus with shaft curved beyond midlength ( Fig. 10K ).....................................................................................................
M. kanakapurensis Viraktamath

22. Relatively small and slender species, less than 3.5 mm long; style apex foot-shaped ( Fig. 10E )....
M. kolarensis Viraktamath
- Relatively larger species, more than 3.5 mm long; style apex not foot shaped ( Fig.10 C–D).......................... 23

23. Style considerably narrowed near apex, apex without pigmentation ( Fig. 10D )....................
M. orientalis (Distant)

- Style gradually narrowed to rounded and pigmented apex ( Fig. 10C )..........................
M. ganeshai Viraktamath
24. Aedeagal shaft with subapical triangular expansion in lateral view ( Figs 5G , 10S ); style apex pigmented ( Fig. 5C )....... 25

- Aedeagal shaft without subapical triangular expansion in lateral view ( Fig. 10L ); style apex not pigmented ( Fig. 10A )......................................................................................
M. lovedalensis (Distant)

25. Pale brown species; style apex in lateral view curved dorsally without constriction ( Fig. 10A )....
M. linnavuorii Viraktamath

- Pale green species; style apex in lateral view curved dorsad and with basal constriction ( Fig. 5C ).......................................................................................................
M. dalhousiensis
sp. nov .
